section.title: Versioning Input Files for an Appliance
section.para: To track and audit any changes to the Spin files that are critical to the definition, configuration and scripts of an appliance, use a revision control system, such as Mercurial or Subversion. The Red Hat-based Linux OS' that Spin works with by default (RHEL, CentOS and Fedora) all have the revision control system Subversion (svn) installed as a development server. Subversion remains the most popular revision control system. For the type of files and distributed nature of Spin, though, the revision control system Mercurial (hg) may be a better option. Mercurial is fast and distributed. Both svn and hg work with secure protocols -- ssh and https.

While everything could be revision controlled, there are some key non-image files that should be. Within the Spin infrastructure and appliance building process, candidates for revision control include configuration files, appliance definition files and scripts, i.e. files that contain critical textual information that may change over time or are commonly used to define aspects of multiple appliances, such as common repositories or network configuration.

If you decide to not use a revision control system, you could rename the .appliance file or other key files every time you make a change to help you "version" your appliance. You can also enter comments in the files. Keep in mind that changing the name of the .appliance file does not mean Spin will build a new appliance. As long as the $APPLIANCEID remains the same, the appliance remains the same.
